>Malcolm Sparks wrote:
>
>> Good stuff. I acc=
ept all the good points made about using 
>assertions in
>> unit tests. But=
 the point I was making about logging was echoing this
>> sentiment:
>> 
>>=
 "Logging equips the developer with detailed context for application
>> fai=
lures. On the other hand, testing provides quality assurance and
>> confide=
nce in the application. Logging and testing should not be
>> confused. They=
 are complementary. When logging is wisely used, it can
>> prove to be an e=
ssential tool."
>> http://jakarta.apache.org/log4j/docs/index.html
>
>Yep. =
The problem is when one uses logging as a substitute for testing, 
>which i=
s still very, very common.
>
>In my opinion, one logs to help provide the c=
ontext for complex 
>troubleshooting. For anything simpler, one tests.
>
>R=
easonable?
